title-group.article-title: Influence of polypropylene fibers on preparation and performance of Fe-modified PAN/PP blended yarns and their knitted fabrics

article-meta.aff: 1Advanced Textile & Composite Materials Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education, Tianjin Polytechnic University, People's Republic of China
2State Key Laboratory Breeding Base of Photocatalysis, Fuzhou University, People's Republic of China
3Engineering Teach Practice Training Center, Tianjin Polytechnic University, People's Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Y Dong, Advanced Textile & Composite Materials Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education, Tianjin Polytechnic University, Tianjin 300387, People's Republic of China. Email: dye@tjpu.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Five blended yarns were spun with polyacrylonitrile (PAN) fibers and polypropylene (PP) fibers at different blending ratios, and then knitted into fabrics. The obtained blended yarns or knitted fabrics were modified using successive amidoximation and coordination with Fe3+ ions to prepare the Fe-modified PAN/PP blended yarns or knitted fabrics. They were used as the heterogeneous Fenton catalysts for the degradation of a typical azo dye, Reactive Red 195, to investigate the effect of fiber blending ratio on the modification, as well as mechanic and catalytic performance. The results indicated that increasing PP fiber content led to a linear increase in the conversion degree of cyano groups to amidoxime groups and Fe content fixed on the surface of PAN fibers in the blend yarn or fabric. PP fibers showed a significant effect on the breaking strength and elongation at break of the blended yarn, and a critical PP fiber content was found to obtain minimum values for strength and elongation. This is due mainly to a large difference in extensibility between the two fibers. The strength and elongation of the obtained knitted fabric were greatly improved by the addition of PP fibers. On the other hand, the blended yarns and knitted fabrics with higher PP fiber content exhibited comparatively stronger catalytic activity.

body.p: In recent years, the heterogeneous Fenton process has become a research focus for the degradation of organic pollutants in water because of its unique advantages on a wide range of pH limitations and easy regeneration.1,2 The modified polyacrylonitrile (PAN) fiber Fe complexes, as heterogeneous Fenton catalysts, are regarded as attractive catalytic materials with advantages including low-cost, suitable chemicals and easy separation of the catalyst after the reaction.3–5 Moreover, the amidoximation of PAN fiber is the conversion of its nitrile groups on the surface to amidoxime groups with hydroxylamine, and the amidoximated PAN fiber has shown a great potential for this application due to its high tendency to form strong complexes with a wide range of metal ions and ease of synthesis.6–8 It is a fact that the mechanical properties of a catalyst is of importance if it is going to have an efficient catalytic life. Thus, good mechanical performance is necessary for effective use of the fibers as catalysts for a Fenton system. However, Lin et al.7,8 and El-Shishtawy and Ahmed9 found that the amidoximation could destroy the paracrystalline region in PAN fiber and in turn lead to a decrease in the tensile strength, especially at higher temperatures during the reaction. In our recent work,10 the breaking strength of the amidoximated PAN fiber was found to be further lowered after coordinating with Fe ions. The modified PAN fiber Fe complex cannot meet the demands for rapid and stable degradation in future commercial applications, and therefore it must be improved to obtain excellent catalytic activity and good mechanical properties. It has been suggested that the activity of the modified PAN fiber Fe complex can often be improved by increasing the Fe content or incorporation of assistant metal ions. However, the detailed information on the addition of other fibers as assistant fibers to improve the mechanical performance of the modified PAN fiber Fe complex is very limited. In this paper, the feasibility of fiber blending was investigated for obtaining fibrous heterogeneous Fenton catalysts with better activity and mechanical performance, because it is common practice to use more than one fiber to optimize the cost and quality of yarns in the textile industry. Furthermore, an important functional property that can be modified by fiber blending is yarn strength.11,12 In addition, the mechanical performance could be increased by integrating inlay fibers into knitted structures.13 Generally, mixing partners for fiber blending are selected on the basis of their cost and properties. It is well known that polypropylene (PP) fiber is a low-cost synthetic fiber that shows many satisfactory physical and chemical properties, such as high strength and initial modulus, excellent elasticity and chemical stability.14 Some researchers15,16 have also reported that the PP fibers have excellent alkali resistance in comparison with other polymeric fibers, such as PAN fiber. Therefore, PP fibers were used to mix with PAN fibers by the spinning process to form PAN/PP blended yarns for knitted fabrics. Then, these yarns or fabrics were modified using amidoximation and Fe coordination to prepare the amidoximated PAN/PP fiber-Fe complexes for the dye degradation. The effect of fiber blending ratio on the modification process, catalytic activity and mechanical performance of these yarns or fabrics was also investigated and discussed.

sec.title: Materials and reagents
sec.p:
The PAN and PP fibers were obtained from Shanghai Petrochemical Co., China, and their specifications are presented in Table 1. Hydroxylamine hydrochloride, sodium hydroxide, ferric chloride and hydrogen peroxide (30% w/w) were of analytical grade and all purchased from Tianjin kemel Chemical Reagent Co., China. Reactive Red 195 (RR 195) is commercially available and used in this experiment without further purification. The molecular structure of the dye is shown in Scheme 1. Double-distilled and deionized water was used throughout the study. Scheme 1.
Chemical structure of Reactive Red 195. Table 1.
Raw material specifications
Material Linear density(dtex) Length (mm) Strength (cN/tex) Elongation (%)
PAN fiber 1.67 38 4.92 24.3
PP fiber 1.51 38 5.11 60.1
PAN: polyacrylonitrile, PP: polypropylene

sec.title: Spinning and knitting processes
sec.p: PAN fibers and PP fibers were firstly opened and blended at different ratios of 100/0, 85/15, 70/30, 50/50 and 30/70 on the opening and blending machine and carding frame system. After drawing and roving, the produced card slivers were spun into 30-tex blended yarns using a laboratory ring spinning machine with a twist of 165 t/m. The yarn tests were conducted at 20 ± 2°C and 65 ± 5% relative humidity (RH) after staples had been conditioned for 48 h. Then, each type of yarn was knitted in a 12-gauge single-jersey structure using a computerized flat knitting machine with one passive feed input under standard atmospheric conditions.

sec.title: Amidoximation of PAN/PP blended yarn or fabric
sec.p: Before amidoximation, the PAN/PP blended yarn or fabric was treated with a solution containing 1.0 g/l sodium carbonate and 2.0 g/l of soap at 50°C for 30 min, and then thoroughly washed with distilled water and dried under vacuum and weighed. Afterwards, the dried samples were added into an aqueous solution in a flask with a thermometer and agitator; the weight ratio of PAN fiber, hydroxylamine hydrochloride and sodium was kept at 1:1.4:0.48. The mixture was heated for a given time (45–120 min) with stirring at 68°C. After reaction, the amidoximated PAN/PP blended yarn or fabric (denoted as AO-PAN/PP yarn or fabric) was taken out and washed with distilled water until neutral pH was reached, and then dried under vacuum. The obtained AO-PAN/PP yarn or fabric was weighed. It should be pointed out that PAN fibers in the blend yarn or fabric were only modified because of the very high chemical stability of PP fiber.15,16 Thus, the conversion degree of cyano groups to amidoxime groups (denoted as CD%) on the surface of PAN fibers in the blend yarn or fabric was calculated based on the weight of PAN fibers in the yarn or fabric according to Equation (1): (1)CD %=(W1-W0)×53W0(1-ω)×33×0.8 7 where W0 and W1 are the weights (g) of the PAN/PP yarns or fabrics before and after amidoximation, respectively. ω is the weight percentage of PP fibers in the untreated PAN/PP yarns or fabrics. The number 53 is the molecular weight of -CH2-CH(CN)- and 33 is the molecular weight of hydroxylamine. The weight ratio of acrylonitrile monomer in PAN fiber (0.87) is determined by nitrogen content (22.97%) in the PAN fiber using the element analytical method.4

sec.title: Coordination of Fe3+ ions with AO-PAN/PP yarn or fabric
sec.p: According to our previous work,10 1.0 g of the AO-PAN/PP yarn or fabric was immersed in an aqueous solution of ferric chloride with the concentration of 0.10 mol/l at pH 2–3 for 24 h under continuous agitation at room temperature to prepare the amidoximated PAN/PP fiber Fe complex (denoted as Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarn or fabric). Then, the resulting Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarn or fabric was repeatedly washed with distilled water until no chloride ions were present in the solution and, finally, it was dried under atmospheric condition. The residual concentration of Fe3+ ions in the solutions after coordination was determined by using a WXF120 atomic absorption spectrometer (Beijing Rayleigh Analytical Instrument Co.). The Fe content (CFe-PAN) of Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarn or fabric was calculated as follows: (2)CFe-PAN=(C0-C1)×V×56W2(1-ω) where C0 and C1 are the initial and residual concentrations (mol/l) of Fe3+ ions in the solution before and after reaction, respectively. V is the volume of the solution (l) and 56 is the molar mass of iron. W2 is the weight (g) of Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarns or fabric.

sec.title: Breaking strength and elongation
sec.p: Before testing, yarn or fabric samples were conditioned at 25°C and 65% RH for at least 48 hours. Then, the breaking strength and elongation at break of the yarn or fabric were measured using a YG 061 laboratory yarn tensile tester and a YG 065 laboratory fabric tensile tester (Laizhou Electronic Instrument Co., China), respectively, under ambient atmosphere conditions according to the Chinese Standard GB/T3916-1997, based on ISO 2062:1993, and GB/T 3923.1-1997, based on ISO/DIS 13934.1-94. The data shown correspond to averages of at least five individual tests for each sample.

sec.title: Catalytic activity
sec.p: According to our previous work,4 Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarn or fabric was assessed as the heterogeneous Fenton catalyst for the oxidative decoloration of RR 195 under visible irradiation in a specially designed photoreaction system. A cut-off filter was used to ensure irradiation only by visible light (λ > 420 nm). The intensity of visible light irradiation over the surface of the test solution was measured to be 8.48 m W/cm2 using an FZ-A radiometer (Beijing BNU Light and Electronic Instrumental Co.). All the degradation experiments were carried out in 100 ml of test solution containing 0.05 mmol/l dye and 3.0 mmol/l H2O2 at an initial pH of 6.0 and 25°C in the presence of 0.50 g of yarn or fabric. At given time intervals, 1–2 ml of the test solution was withdrawn from the reaction vessel and analyzed on a UV-2401 spectrophotometer (Shimadzu Co., Japan). The decoloration percentage of RR 195 was expressed as (3)D %=(1-Cd/Cd0)×1 00% where Cd0 and Cd are the initial concentration and the residual concentration of RR 195 (mmol/l), respectively.

sec.title: Effect of fiber blending ratio on the modification process
sec.p: The modification of the PAN/PP blended yarn or fabric began with the conversion of the nitrile groups on the surface of the PAN fiber to amidoxime groups in hydroxylamine solution. The obtained AO-PAN/PP yarn or fabric then was reacted with Fe3+ ions in solution to form Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarn or fabric. The two reactions are depicted by Equations (4) and (5):

Five PAN/PP blended yarns or fabrics with different fiber blending ratios were amidoximated; their CD% values were measured and are shown in Figure 1. The regression equations for the relationship between PP fiber content or weight percentage of PP fiber in the blended yarn (denoted as CPP%) and CD% value are shown in Table 2. Figure 1.
CD% values of AO-PAN/PP yarns and fabrics with different PP fiber contents. Table 2.
Regression equations between CPP% and CD% or CFe-PAN values
Samples Regression equations R
AO-PAN/PP Yarn CD% = 0.266 CPP% + 36.2 (6) 0.9831
Fabric CD% = 0.341 CPP% + 16.1 (7) 0.9925
Fe-AO-PAN/PP Yarn CFe-PAN = 0.796 CPP% + 149 (8) 0.9703
Fabric CFe-PAN = 1.41 CPP% + 78.3 (9) 0.9909

Figure 1 and Table 2 show that increasing the CPP% value in AO-PAN/PP yarn and fabric led to a liner increase in their CD% values, suggesting that the presence of PP fibers was beneficial for the amidoximation of PAN fibers in the blended yarns and fabrics. The main reason may be that PP fiber has a much smoother surface than PAN fiber,17 which reduced the cohesive force between the fibers within the blended yarn or fabric structure, thus turning it loose. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the fibers in the blended yarns after the modification are also provided in Figure 2 to show the difference in fibrous structure between PP and PAN fibers. PAN fibers were found to shrink a lot after the amidoximation, which was reported by the gradual increase in their elongation at breaking as weight gain rate increased.10 Consequently, another possible explanation is that the addition of PP fibers limited the shrinkage of the blended yarn due to the modification of PAN fibers during the reaction. These can enhance the penetration of hydroxylamine hydrochloride into the yarn or fabric to accelerate the modification of PAN fiber. Moreover, it is found that AO-PAN/PP yarn exhibits much higher CD% values than AO-PAN/PP fabric at the same fiber blending ratio, demonstrating that PAN fibers in the yarn can more easily be modified with hydroxylamine hydrochloride than those in the fabric. This is because when yarns were knitted to be fabric, the fibers in the yarn are further compacted, thus significantly limiting the penetration of hydroxylamine hydrochloride into the yarn. Figure 2.
Scanning electron microscopy images of Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarn with different PP fiber contents.

In order to examine the impact of fiber blending ratio on the Fe content of Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarn or fabric, the obtained AO-PAN/PP yarns or fabrics with different fiber blending rations reacted with Fe3+ ions to produce Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarns or fabrics; their CFe-PAN values are shown in Figure 3. The regression equations between CPP% and CFe-PAN values are given in Table 2. Figure 3.
Linear relationship between CFe value and PP fiber content.

The data in Table 2 indicate that there is a better linear relationship between CPP% and CFe-PAN values, because the obtained correlation coefficients are above 0.95. Figure 2 shows that the CFe-PAN value of Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarn increases proportionally as the CPP% value increases. This is mainly attributed to the higher CD% values of AO-PAN/PP yarn with higher CPP% values, as indicated in Table 1. Another explanation is that PP fibers may reduce the shrinkage of the blended yarn due to the modification of PAN fibers, consequently improving the PAN fiber exposure to hydroxylamine hydrochloride. Also, Fe-AO-PAN/PP fabric has a similar CFe-PAN variation with CPP% to Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarn. However, the CFe-PAN values are lower than those for Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarn at the same CPP%, which is greatly dependent on low CD% values of AO-PAN/PP fabrics. Furthermore, it should be noted that the difference in CFe-PAN value between yarn and fabric gradually decreased with increasing CPP% value. The slope of Equation (9) for fabric is higher than that of Equation (8) for yarn. This result proposes that PP fibers display a stronger inhibiting effect on shrinkage of the fabrics during the modification of PAN fibers.

sec.title: Effect of fiber blending ratio on mechanical properties
Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarns
sec.p:
To investigate the influence of fiber blending ratio on the mechanical properties of the blended yarn, the breaking strength and elongation at break of the blended yarn before and after modification and coordination were measured and are shown in Figure 4. Figure 4.
(a) Breaking strength and (b) elongation at break of the blended yarn.

Figure 4 shows that the breaking strength and elongation at break of the blended yarns varied significantly with CPP% value; both minimum values were observed with the addition of 30% PP fiber. They gradually rose above the minimum value. This is owing to the big difference in extensibility between PP and PAN fibers. As indicated in Table 1, PP fiber exhibited much better elongation than PAN fiber; thus, it was regarded as a rather extensible fiber. For this reason, there was a drop in breaking strength and elongation when a small percentage of PP fiber was added to PAN yarn. With the addition of more than 30% PP fiber, the strength and elongation of the yarn began to increase. In the same way, when nylon as a rather extensible fiber is combined with a comparatively inextensible fiber, such as cotton to form a blended yarn, a similar strength variation with fiber blending ratio has also been found.18 On the other hand, it is found from Figure 4 that the breaking strength of the blended yarn decreases remarkably through amidoximation and coordination. Moreover, the breaking strength of Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarn is the lowest. This is because both reaction processes lead to low crystallization and orientation of the PAN fibers.4,9 It is worth noting that amidoximation causes a significant increase in elongation at break of the blended yarns, which may be due to the obvious shrinkage of the yarn after the modification, thus enhancing its elasticity. In addition, our previous work19 reported that the Fe3+ ion can link the adjacent molecular chains in the amorphous regions of PAN fibers by means of a coordinating reaction, thus decreasing the breaking strength and elongation at break, as a result of the lesser uniformity of fiber molecular structure.

sec.title: Fe-AO-PAN/PP fabrics
sec.p:
Different PAN/PP knitted fabrics with different fiber blending ratios were modified through amidoximation and coordination, and then their mechanical properties were tested, the results of which are presented in Figure 5. The regression equations between CPP% and the elongation at break (E%) were also build, as shown in Table 3. Figure 5.
(a) Breaking strength and (b) elongation at break of PAN/PP knitted fabric. Table 3.
Regression equation between CPP% and E% values
Fabrics Regression equations R
PAN/PP E% = 0.271CPP% + 63.9 (10) 0.9805
AO-PAN/PP E% = 0.329CPP% + 68.2 (11) 0.9767
Fe-AO-PAN/PP E% = 0.437 CPP% + 36.1 (12) 0.9873

As can be seen from Figure 5, PAN/PP knitted fabrics show much higher breaking strength and elongation at break than the corresponding blended yarns because they consist of a series of interlinked loops of yarn.18 More importantly, it is apparent that increasing the breaking strength and elongation at break of PAN/PP knitted fabric is accompanied by an increasing CPP% value. A better linear relationship between CPP% and elongation at break is observed for three samples. This implies that PP fibers make a significant contribution to improve the mechanical properties of the knitted fabric through their better extensibility and stronger tangles with PAN fibers. Moreover, like the blended yarn, a decrease in the mechanical properties, especially strength of the knitted fabric, is observed after modification and coordination. However, it is believed that such mechanical properties are strong enough for PAN/PP knitted fabrics to act as effective Fenton catalysts for the treatment of dyeing wastewater.

sec.title: Effect of fiber blending ratio on catalytic activity
sec.p:
Five of the Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarns or fabrics containing a similar amount (68.2 mg) of Fe3+ ions were used as the heterogeneous Fenton catalysts for the degradation of RR 195 under visible irradiation by adjusting their weight added into the reaction system. For comparison, a control experiment, in which the Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarn or fabric was absent in the reaction system, was carried out. The decoloration percentages of RR 195 in the absence or presence of the yarn or fabric are given in Figure 6. Moreover, the pseudo-first-order rate constants (k) of dye decoloration from Figure 6 within 60 min of reaction time were calculated from linear regression ln (Cd 0/Cd) versus time plots with all regression coefficients >0.98, and are listed in Table 4. Figure 6.
Variations in D% value of Reactive Red 195 catalyzed by Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarns or fabrics with different fiber blending ratios. Table 4.
k values in the presence or absence of Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarn or fabric
CPP%Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarnFe-AO-PAN/PP fabric
k (min–1)Rk (min–1)R
0 0.0227 0.9979 0.0148 0.9963
15 0.0273 0.9985 0.0194 0.9971
30 0.0323 0.9986 0.0252 0.9946
50 0.0388 0.9995 0.0321 0.9922
70 0.0483 0.9993 0.0405 0.9892
Control 0.0013 0.9918 0.0013 0.9918

Figure 6 shows that the D% value is less than 5.0% without the yarn or fabric after 120 min of the reaction under visible irradiation, demonstrating that the decomposition rate of RR 195 is rather slow. It is clearly found that when the yarn or fabric was used, the D% value significantly increased with the prolongation of reaction time under visible irradiation. The k value with the yarn or fabric is much higher than that for the control experiment. These results suggest that Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarns or fabrics have stronger catalytic activity on dye degradation. This is because the yarn or fabric can enhance the reduction of the loaded Fe3+ to Fe2+ ions through the Fenton-like process under visible irradiation, and the generated Fe2+ ions are then oxidized immediately by H2O2 to complete the Fe3+/Fe2+ ions cycle and produce hydroxyl radicals, which can be responsible for the dye degradation. This reaction process is described by Equations (13) and (14): (13)Fe3+/PAN+H2O2hv→Fe2+/PAN+HO2•+H⊕ (14)Fe2+/PAN+H2O2hv→Fe3+/PAN+OH⊙+HO•

Figure 6 and Table 4 depict that higher CPP% values give rise to a gradual increase in the D% and k values of the dye, indicating that the catalytic performance of the yarn or fabric is affected by the incorporation of PP fibers. This may be owing to their smooth surface, which loosens the structure of the yarn or fabric and reduces the resistance of the reaction solution moving between the fibers, thus accelerating the penetration and diffusion of dye and H2O2 molecules inside the yarn or fabric, resulting in the relatively fast adsorption of the dye molecules into the yarn or fabric, especially PAN fibers during the degradation. The yarn has a higher k value than the fabric at the same CPP% value. This is in relation to the more compact structure of the fabric, which can retard the penetration and diffusion of the dye and H2O2 molecules within the fibers, thus limiting the dye degradation with H2O2 in the presence of the yarn or fabric.

The adsorption of RR 195 on Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarns or fabrics with different CPP% values was examined at room temperature under visible irradiation (Figure 7), because it is necessary that a good heterogeneous catalyst should adsorb the reactant molecules strongly enough for them to react. Figure 7 shows that the higher CPP% value caused a significant increase in the adsorption amount of RR 195 (Qdye) on Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarns or fabric. It should be pointed out that the enhanced Qdye value may be attributed to the PAN fibers in the yarn or fabric, since PP fibers with smooth surface and stronger hydrophobicity adsorb water-soluble dyes with great difficulty under such conditions. Furthermore, the Qdye value for the yarn is higher than that for the fabric at the same reaction time. H2O2 decomposition profiles during the degradation of RR 195 in the presence of Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarn or fabric with different CPP% values were investigated, and results are given in Figure 8. Figure 7.
Reactive Red 195 adsorption on Fe-AO-PAN/PP fabrics with different PP fiber contents. Figure 8.
Decay of 6.0 mmol l−1 H2O2 during the degradation of Reactive Red 195.

Figure 8 shows that the decay ratio for H2O2 in solution significantly decreased with prolongation of reaction time in the presence of Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarn or fabric. It is worth noting that Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarn or fabric with a higher CPP% value can accelerate H2O2 decomposition at the same conditions, which leads to a faster generation of hydroxyl radicals in solution by the heterogeneous photo-Fenton reaction,12 thus promoting dye degradation. Moreover, lower decay ratios for H2O2 in the presence of the yarns were observed than in the presence of the fabrics, implying that the yarns exhibit stronger catalytic activity for H2O2 decomposition than the fabric at the same conditions.

sec.title: Recycling property of the Fe-AO-PAN/PP fabric
sec.p:
The recycling property of Fe-AO-PAN/PP fabric as the catalyst was examined by the additional degradation process of fresh dye solution with the used catalysts from the previous runs. The used catalysts were thoroughly washed with distilled water after each run, and dye and H2O2 were added before the next run. Fe-AO-PAN/PP fabric with CPP% of 70% was reused up to five times; the result is presented in Figure 9. Figure 9.
Catalytic recycling of Fe-AO-PAN/PP fabric with CPP% of 70% at initial pH 6.0 under visible light irradiation during repetitive degradation of Reactive Red 195.

Figure 9 shows that although the catalytic activity of Fe-AO-PAN/PP fabric was lost after each cycle, the D% value of the dye in the fifth run was about 60%. This indicated that Fe-AO-PAN/PP fabric could be reused five times. Moreover, little decrease in the CFe-PAN value of the fabric was found after five successive runs.

sec.title: Industrial impact and future plans
sec.p: PAN and PP fibers are the man-made fibers commonly used in the modern textile industry throughout the world. Moreover, both of them are available commercially at a low cost. More importantly, PAN fiber is easily modified with hydroxylamine by partial conversion of its nitrile groups into amidoxime groups, which is then used to react with Fe3+ ions using a simple exhaustion method at low temperature. The regeneration of the used catalyst using alcohol and water is also inexpensive. Compared with some heterogeneous Fenton catalysts, such as Nafion membrane20 and other modified PAN fibrous catalysts,3 the Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarn or fabric shows a better catalytic activity for the more effective degradation of organic dye in water and has other advantages, such as low cost, easy preparation and good regenerative property. Consequently, it is believed that Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarn or fabric is of practical importance in an industrial scale. In order to further improve its catalytic activity, the future plan for this work is increasing the Fe content or the incorporation of a Cu2+ ion as the assistant metal ion when preparing the Fe-AO-PAN/PP yarn or fabric.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: PP fibers were combined with PAN fibers to produce PAN/PP blended yarns with different fiber blending ratios, which were then knitted into fabrics. By means of successive amidoximation and coordination with Fe3+ ions, the knitted fabrics were modified to form effective heterogeneous Fenton catalysts with better catalytic and mechanical performance for the degradation of organic dye in water. Increasing the PP fiber content resulted in a proportional increase in both CD% and CFe-PAN values of the yarns or fabrics during the modification. PP fibers showed a significant effect on the mechanical properties of the yarn, and a critical PP fiber content was found, at which it shows minimum values for strength and elongation. This is mainly attributed to a large difference in extensibility between the two fibers. In contrast, when PP fibers were added to the PAN yarns, the strength and elongation of the obtained knitted fabric were greatly enhanced as PP fiber content increased. On the other hand, the catalytic activity of the blended yarn or knitted fabric was improved by the addition of PP fibers. The yarn exhibited higher catalytic activity than the fabric at the same PP fiber content. Most of the dyes were decomposed in water within 120 min in the presence of the blended yarn or knitted fabric with higher PP fiber content. As a result, maximum breaking strength and catalytic activity for the dye degradation of the blended yarn and knitting fabric was found when PAN fibers and PP fibers were spun at a blending ratio of 30/70.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the Tianjin Municipal Science and Technology Committee Research Program of Application Foundation and Advanced Technology (11JCZDJ24600). This work was also supported in part by a grant from the Natural Science Foundation of China (20773093).
